discussion.content:
The SBC stores an internal binding between the AOR and the original contact of the user. It includes:
•The Contact URI sent by the UA in the REGISTER message, the originating IP Address and port, the user’s realm, and the Contact URI sent to the registrar
•The userinfo in the Contact URI sent to the registrar includes the original userinfo from the UA, followed by an encoded cookie
Correct answer: C

comments.content: I disagree, correct answer is E. In fact what you copy/pasted says exactly that: “original contact” which is not L3 IP.

questions.question_text: How does the SIP registrar server maintain the registered user’s information in its database?

choices.D: by creating a location record, which is an association between the Call-ID and the User Agent (UA) Contact address
choices.E: by creating a binding, which is an association between a globally unique SIP URI and the User Agent (UA) Contact address
choices.C: by creating a registration cache entry, which is an association between a layer 3 IP address and the User Agent (UA) Via address

questions.question_text:
You are logged in to the Session Border Controller a superuser. You want to remove other user from the system.
How do you accomplish this?

discussion.content:
In superuser mode after "show user" command, you can close a session by using "kill <index number>"
Correct answer: D

choices.D: from the superuser mode, by executing the kill <index number> command
choices.B: from the user mode, by executing the kill <index number> command
choices.A: from the superuser mode, by executing the remove user <index number> command
choices.C: from the superuser mode, by executing the remove user <username> command
choices.E: from the user mode, by executing the remove user <index number> command

questions.question_text:
You are configuring the boot parameters in the Session Border Controller.
Which three statements are true about the boot parameters? (Choose three.)

choices.B: The target name is used for domain name resolution.
choices.A: A reboot is always required to apply any change to the boot parameters.
choices.C: The system clock is a boot parameter.
choices.D: The boot parameters are stored in Non-Volatile Random Access Memory (NVRAM).
choices.E: The boot parameters are not affected by the activate-config command.

discussion.content:
The system clock is NOT a boot parameter
Correct answers: ADE

comments.content: You are right ... activate config is affect only RTC changes

choices.A: It sends a periodic re-register command to each endpoint behind a NAT.
choices.D: It sends SIP OPTIONS at increasing intervals to test if an endpoint behind a NAT device is still reachable.
choices.C: It creates a binding for the Address of Record (AOR) of an endpoint that is NOT behind a NAT.
choices.E: It sends ICMP PNGs to dynamically learn the binding time of an endpoint behind a NAT device.
choices.B: It creates a binding for the Address of Record (AOR) of an endpoint that is behind a NAT.

questions.question_text: What does the Session Border Controller do when the Adaptive Hosted NAT (HNT) feature is enabled?

discussion.content:
The SBC is dynamically determining, for each endpoint, the logest "expires=" value (returned to it in the 200 OK)
The test timer is initialized to the same value as the nat-interval (30 sec). The initial value chosen for the “Expires=” is the test timer value + 10 sec (=40 sec). Thirty seconds after sending the 200 OK, the SBC sends an unsolicited SIP message (It uses the OPTIONS method for that.) and waits for a SIP response (It is assumed that the firewall does not return any SIP response.). A SIP response is returned; therefore, the test is successful and a longer “Expires=” value will be attempted upon the next REGISTER request.
Correct answer: D

Correct answers are IMO A and D. home-proxy-address value pertains to SIP-NAT, not HMR. B is wrong because there’s no relation between PBRB and HMR; C is wrong because the name to be put in sip-interface is the sip-manipulation name and not name of header-rule. D could be a reason for HMR not working.

choices.D: The value of the match-val-type parameter is not written correctly.
choices.C: The value of the name parameter in the header-rule configuration element is different than the value of the out-manipulationid parameter in the sip-interface configuration element.
choices.A: You have not configured the out-manipulationid parameter of the sip-interface configuration element.
choices.B: You have not enabled policy-based realm-bridging.
choices.E: The home-proxy-address value does not match the $LOCAL_IP value in the new-value parameter.

questions.question_text:
After configuring Header Manipulation Rules (HMRs) for topology hiding, your subsequent testing shows that the manipulation is not taking effect.
Identify two causes for this (Choose two.)
